ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect phenotypic match with reference Case 1, presenting with both clinodactyly and abnormal facial shape. Kabuki syndrome 2 is X-linked, consistent with male patient.
Also presents with clinodactyly and characteristic facial features. More common than type 2, autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
Features clinodactyly (especially of 5th fingers) and distinctive facial features including downslanting palpebral fissures and broad nasal bridge.
Similar presentation to RTS1 with clinodactyly and facial dysmorphism, caused by EP300 mutations rather than CREBBP.
Can present with fifth finger clinodactyly and coarse facial features, though typically has more severe intellectual disability.
Common cause of clinodactyly (5th finger) and characteristic facial features including upslanting palpebral fissures and flat facial profile.
Can present with clinodactyly of 5th fingers and triangular facial shape, though growth restriction is typically prominent.
While reference cases show facial abnormalities, typical features include cardiac defects and immunodeficiency not present in this patient.
